commentBody:
Fine puzzle, but a Wednesday Thursday.

To me, it's not a Thursday if I'm never INJEOPARDY.

YMMV.

A(2) 20.39

No look up

I see complaints about this not being a Thursday puzzle, but I don‚Äôt care ‚Äî it was a lot of fun! (Anyhow, complaints about a puzzle being too easy usually come from people who finish quickly and post early. Not really representative.)

I thought this was delightful, but I did miss my Thursday mindbender. Even the fill wasn‚Äôt too tricky except for the SE. To be a little nitty‚ÄîI don‚Äôt mind an occasional regionalism but WHAP and THAR seemed overkill in the same puzzle especially since the signal for THAR seemed more archaic than regional.

Will,

It was so much fun! It went by wayyy tooo quickly! More like that please!

As a long time Jeopardy fan (going back to the Art Fleming Days) I got a kick out of this puzzle although it wasn‚Äôt particularly gimmicky for a Thursday, as the themed clues were pretty straightforward.  I did appreciate that they resolved into common phrases.

Seeing JUMP scare put me in mind of one of the best of all time:  Alan Arkin lunging at Audrey Hepburn in her darkened apartment at the end of Wait Until Dark.  There are good ones in Alien and Night Of The Living Dead too.

To Francis‚ÄîI responded to you
late on yesterday‚Äôs comments but you probably didn‚Äôt see it, I hope you read this today.

Francis‚ÄîI apologize about the spelling of your name and I am horrified you took yesterday‚Äôs comment completely the wrong way. I have a lot of respect for you and I apologize it came off that way. What I meant was that some people need to vent politically and you are certainly one of those people, and that I have learned to accept that about this or any forum. It‚Äôs certainly evident that these days people have a lot of frustration that bubbles over and gets triggered by all sorts of things. (My LGBTQ comment was to point out conservatives that get their shorts in a bind as well‚Äîsee Felicia today). I try to play the peacemaker or just ignore that stuff because I do like to think of crosswords as my safe haven. I just meant it as a good natured jest and thought you would take it that way, but obviously you have a lot on your mind and I don‚Äôt know what you may be going through. If I offended you I sincerely apologize. Please‚Äîfriends again?
My fav puzzle so far this year. What a treat!

Love the puzzle, and the ASWAN joke had me giggling. 

Love even more the Dr. Glaucomflecken reference in the column. Everything about Dr G is awesome!
This puzzle gets a 10/10 from me just for the ASWAN joke.

A delightful tribute to my favorite game show. 

But a missed opportunity to clue 60A as ‚ÄúFleming who originally hosted this puzzle‚Äôs theme‚Äù.

48d took me a while to figure out at the end. Why not just clue 60a as the old NYC subway and keep WHIP with the same clue at 48d? To me, WHAP is the sound of swatting someone with a rolled up newspaper, not actually beating them.

And while the theme is fun, I don't think the revealer works, unless this is another regional thing? Do people say they heard the answer 'in Jeopardy!' or 'on Jeopardy!'? I would only ever say 'on'.
I loved it. How many people who love a daily crossword challenge probably watch Jeopardy and Wheel of fortune? Trivia and letter sussing. What a treat!
Loved it, but a bit easy for a Thursday in my book. I think it would fit nicely as a Wednesday.

Very well done! The TV show was obvious, but I didn‚Äôt catch on to how it played out as quickly as I should have. Saw the gimmick with WHATSUP - a charming, bittersweet little movie. And I confidently put in nitrO for 2D, which ground me to a halt for a time. Not the impossibility of so many Thursdays - fine by me!
Nice to see 16 across.   But my Jade‚Äôs job is being the bestest friend and soulmate.
Once I got CanCan replaced by CHACHA I started to swing! Duped by the recent TOUCAN I supposeüòâ

Some Thursdays you'd just as soon have a Wednesday.  

Thank you, Gene Louise.  Clever cluing, nothing punishing, and plenty of smiles along the way.  I'm happy.
A jaunty little puzzle! I'm surprised 50D didn't get a shout out under Tricky Clues, as I was very confident it was CANCAN until it made the crossings impossible.

I didn't mind having an easier Thursday puzzle today, especially because I worked it at the end of a trying Wednesday. I was just going about my work when a parent let her cute preschooler practically climb in my lap. Which would've been fine except several minutes in, she mentioned the child who had just rubbed her hair on my sweater had untreated head lice üòÇ. I mean... it would have been nice to know I was INJEOPARDY beforehand. Talk about a JUMPscare!

So I am recovering from having to bag my favorite work sweater for 2 weeks and put a noxious smelling OTC glop all over my hair, while trying not to imagine I feel something crawling on me. Lol. My ATP was about spent but now I feel renewed!
The RIPA/AERO intersection felt like a Natick to me.

The Venn diagram of crossword nerds and trivia/Jeopardy nerds has a lot of overlap üôãüèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Being in both camps I wanted to love this puzzle with all my heart. But I found the theme answers too easy and the fill a bit clunky and forced, so ultimately it felt a bit unsatisfying. Plus every time lately I see references to government agencies or the Supreme Court I kind of go ü§¢üò†üò¢.

But still, how can I stay mad at a J! puzzle? Especially when we are in reruns waiting for the next season? I am glad others loved it!
Whether this puzzle played on the wrong day or not doesn‚Äôt take away from its enjoyment. Thanks, Gene Louise

Hello solvers!

I‚Äôve never commented before but a few days ago I solved my 2500th puzzle. I‚Äôm really getting into the NYT puzzles, having steadily solved since March of 2023.

This puzzle was my kind of puzzle. Science, pop culture,  the arts and puns‚Ä¶all wrapped up with a clever theme.  Thursday‚Äôs are my most and least favorite days, the tricky themes/solutions can be hit or miss.  But more often than not, they are hits.

I don‚Äôt know exactly why I I felt like this was the puzzle to comment on, but I was so impressed and entertained that I could not help myself.

Thanks for being such a great community and good luck in the future!

This was such a pleasing puzzle to solve. It really hit a sweet spot for me, somewhere there between things I immediately knew, things I quickly deduced, and things I was happy to learn. Throw in also some great misdirects, and what a terrific Thursday puzzle this was! Thank you so much, Mr. De Vera! I loved the double entendre of the themers as well as your in memoriam shout-out to ALEX Trebek. And now, to wrap it up, "I'd like 80's new wave classics for $800..." How about it then ‚Äì here's the great Howard Jones with "WHAT IS LOVE" https://youtu.be/w34vnz_LEX4?si=3NXbLJlg4xNo8Xwq
Nice puzzle, but over too quickly. A new PB for me, in well under half my Thursday average.

It was fine though pretty quick.  The theme was kind of of obvious but cute enough I suppose.  Only the lower right gave me trouble and slowed me down, and even that might be because I'm pretty tired right now.  If I I did grading I'd probably say 7 or maybe eight.

On the bright side my streak is fixed...

‚ÄúWherefore art thou, theme?‚Äù, the caption for the Romeo & Juliet illustration, is a trigger for me. ‚ÄúWherefore‚Äù does not equal ‚Äúwhere,‚Äù it means ‚Äúhow come?‚Äù Which is what Juliet is bemoaning‚Äî ‚ÄúWhy did you have to be ‚ÄòRomeo‚Äô?‚Äù and therefore forbidden.

That is all.

I came to look for 48D in "tricky clues" because neither "Larrup" nor WHAP mean anything at all to me, but for the onomatopoeia of the latter.

Huh.
Very ingenious, if quick. I still have coffee in my cup!

Cute puzzle, but a bit easy for a Thursday. Appreciate the theming and themers. Had to reach deep to come up with 1A. I'm surprised I remembered it. Almost put nitro for 2D, but then remembered it's nitrous, so it had to be something else. "Yonder" finally got me to thinking of a western drawl, and THAR became the obvious choice. I remember gassing up at AMOCO stations occasionally, so that one wasn't tough at all.

Thanks, Gene!
Everyone who heard Bender answering 6D, drink!
A bit easy for a Thursday but a real delight nonetheless - loved it.

Fun but quick!

I'm too lazy to read all the comments to see if someone has already mentioned that 60A should have been clued to Fleming.

A quick word on etymology:

JEOPARDY comes from the French ‚Äújeu parti‚Äù meaning a shared/even game, ie you have not got an advantage and could easily lose. Nothing to do with leopards.
I enjoyed all the trivia, both in the theme answers (WHAT‚ÄôS UP, WHAT‚ÄôS THE TEA) and the others (YEW). More of a Wednesday puzzle in difficulty but that‚Äôs ok. I‚Äôm tired anyway.

Decent Thursday puzzle, cute theme. I feel a bit uncomfortable with 29 Across "Yonder" cluing THAR, because while the word .thar. is a dialectal version of the word .there., the word .yonder. (despite our association of it with rural areas) is standard English.

Knowing absolutely nothing about Jeopardy at all, this still wasn't too challenging for me. 

The hardest bit was not knowing RIPA and TABOO so I also got stuck at AERO (there are so many chocolate bars). 

ASWAN and  ATOLL were nice clues.

APBIO and its clue is a mystery, could someone explain please?

For ATOLL, the clue is ‚Äúkey ring.‚Äù  

Is ‚Äúkey‚Äù necessary?  

90% of the time that word can be dropped with no loss in meaning (‚Äúkey takeaway‚Äù grates particularly).

Or am I missing something?

I haven‚Äôt been a regular Jeopardy! viewer since my childhood in the Art Fleming era. Still, the not-tricky trick was immediately obvious from WHO‚ÄôS THE BOSS?*

I solved this much more slowly than I would have if I hadn‚Äôt been falling asleep when I did this. We went for a three-hour hike at over 9,000‚Äô on a warm, sunny day, so I was quite tired after dinner. 

Anyone else think WHAT‚ÄôS THE TEA is an improbable Jeopardy! response to the clue about Mary Cassat‚Äôs painting? I appreciate the wordplay of TEA/gossip, but the other theme answers all seem like legitimate responses on that show.
My week is topsy-turvy. Monday took longer than Tuesday; Wednesday took longer than Thursday.

To Deb, I‚Äôm pretty sure that USH is meant as a verb here, not a noun. This was a relatively easy Thursday for me maybe because I own a collie (HERD),I love Mary Cassatt (THETEA) and I majored in geology (FJORD and ATOLL). Or perhaps after a few months of solving I‚Äôm getting better at this? The Jeopardy clues were so much fun. I got WHATISLOVE right away and after that the rest were a snap. Bravo!  I think AlLEX would have loved it.
Great theme, but since it didn't have a trick, some toughened up cluing would have been nice.

[‚ÄúI‚Äôll take ‚ÄòAnimals‚Äô for $200, Ken‚Äù]
Savanna prey

WHAT‚ÄôS GNU
What is ‚Äúfun‚Äù?

Very creative puzzle. Easy for the solver (and that's fine) but I imagine it was tough to fit five theme answers and a revealer (plus the bonus Alex) into the grid. And the fill was nonetheless very good -- gettable but not stale.

I admit that I didn't know the name of Canada's second tallest mountain (although I guessed it was in Yukon) -- got that one through the crosses.

The theme felt more Wednesday-ish, but the difficulty felt Thursday. The SW corner, for me,  was the toughest. Who gnu?

tc

A most memorable moment was the face-screwing span I went through after misreading 4A‚Äôs clue as [Prominent feature of a hippocampus or crocodile].




Et tu, emu.

This will be my last time in the comments section. Far be it from me to assume that this was a place where people could come and share their thoughts about the puzzle without engaging in negative or demeaning behavior. It's a crossword puzzle, after all--and unfortunately the bad apples do ruin the whole bunch when all I want is a way to disengage from the otherwise negative world.

Mike, keep the puns going. I'll check back in on them another time.

How did I love this?  Let me count the ways:
‚Ä¢	A dozen answers ending with the OO sound (AFEW, WHOSWHO, GREW, GNU, TABOO, SPEW, STEW, HULU, YEW, SHOO, TWOFORTWO, OOH), and notice all the variations for making that sound.
‚Ä¢	Eight WILs (words I love) ‚Äì LITHE, POSH, GNU, FJORD, GRIFT, SPEW, NINJA, WHAP.  And let me repeat ‚Ä¶ WHAP!
‚Ä¢	Five ways to pick a Jeopardy category (I‚Äôll take‚Ä¶, Let‚Äôs go with‚Ä¶, Give me‚Ä¶, How about‚Ä¶, I‚Äôll try...).
‚Ä¢	Three echoes ‚Äì A SWAN, A SEA, and A TOLL to echo A FEW.
‚Ä¢	Two ugly-ish words so colorful that, IMO, they beautify our language (MEATBAG, RATTRAP).
‚Ä¢	One masterful theme ‚Äì in-the-language phrases beginning with ‚Äúwho‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat‚Äù turned into Jeopardy answers.  A brilliant concept, IMO, never done before.

A gift box today.  Thank you so much for making this, Gene!

This was quite a puzzle. Not all that easy for me of course. I was completely stuck in a number of places for a while, but finally tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point. That's always a nice touch. A rather amazing puzzle find today - A Sunday from July 1, 2007 by Nancy Salomon and Bill Zais with the title "Diamond jubilee." Hard to describe this one. Four rebus squares, each at the corner of an area in the shape of a baseball diamond. Those four rebuses - HOME, FIRST, SECOND, THIRD. And each of those rebus squares was actually a part of THREE answers - one across, one down, and one sliding in at an angle from the other base. Those angular answers: THATSA(FIRST) STEALS(SECOND) FINISH(THIRD) STAYED(HOME) But as one example -HOME was also a part of two other crossing answers - MOBILEHOME and GOHOME. Can't explain it beyond that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/1/2007&g=69&d=A I'll shut up now. ...

I loved this one! Thankfully, I was able to get the ones I didn‚Äôt know from the crosses. Did have to get help with Horatio‚Äôs work. I cannot imagine how difficult it was to construct this puzzle! Thankful for your work!
48d is nonsense. It‚Äôs in Urban Dictionary not the actual dictionary.

Easy solve for a Thursday. More of a theme puzzle than a Thursday stumper, sezs me.  But A treat to see the Jeopardy theme clues and smile and smile and smile. 

What is "A Terrific Thursday". This.
Isn‚Äôt Larrup a whip rather than a whap ?!?

Must be running short of Thursday puzzles at the moment. This one seemed like a Tuesday puzzle to me.

Liked the long verticals PRDISASTER and ARSPOETICA. Didn't like being called a MEATBAG, and was troubled by the repeated references to harm befalling a poor field mouse.

Are the thematic entries specific titles or just phrases? If the latter, then WHATISLOVE with no apostrophe seems out of place here. I guess to me it does in either case.

Would have preferred more fun/mystery on a Thursday.
Seven minute solve.  Two minutes over normal.  (Just kidding.)
There is an expensive restaurant in Forest Hills, NYC, called Ars Poetica. Great Italian food but I didn't see any poets.
A fun puzzle with a clever theme. Nice to see Horace make an appearance. Nicer still: no Marvel comics or gaming questions.

Fun, and clever.
But where's the Thursday difficulty?


Needs a fifth leg to solve.

Enjoyed this. Theme revealed itself early without giving away the puzzle, so that's a great balance IMO.

Enjoyed the dad pun.

Was stuck for a while in NW because I assumed nitro was the booster.
Fun, entertaining and clever. Thank you!

I enjoyed this puzzle, which I solved fairly quickly, by standards at any rate, since I still have a long way to go before my times get near the medians I see on xwstats. Enjoyed the theme and was tickled by the theme answers, especially 41A with its reference to Abbott and Costello‚Äôs classic bit for WHO‚ÄôS WHO? 

I have a question‚Ä¶I‚Äôve only noticed ‚Äútea‚Äù as slang for gossip over the last few years and I generally get clues related to it because it‚Äôs popped up so often in the NYT CW, but I‚Äôve never heard anyone say, WHAT‚ÄôS THE TEA? Is this a regional thing? (I‚Äôm in the US Midwest.) I‚Äôve often heard, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs the dirt?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the skinny?‚Äù or ‚ÄúGive me the deets.‚Äù

This was a great theme for a crossword puzzle. As others have mentioned, I‚Äôm sure there is a lot of overlap in the Venn diagram of NYTXW solvers and Jeopardy! fans. While my enjoyment of the theme does not reach the heights attained by HeathieJ with the Star Trek puzzle of a few days ago, it was still a lot of fun, especially for a Thursday. 

I thought I should give an update to my recent experience that I‚Äôve mentioned here. My lovely sister-in-law unfortunately passed away during the night yesterday while in hospice care at home.  Even though we knew it was coming, we were still surprised by how markedly her condition changed and that she was gone so quickly.  I know that she was well cared for every step of the way, most especially by her husband, my awesome brother Joe.  

Please remember to show love to the people in your life that you love.  It‚Äôs easy to take for granted how important they are to us. üôèüèª

I loved this theme!!

It is so hard not to take it personally when people die right after kissing you.

Fun puzzle, and so much in my wheelhouse--the whole NW corner, and the gimme ARS POETICA. Am I brilliant? No, just a geek.

Plenty of Canadian Culture Content today, with Mt. St. ELIAS, AERO bars, and, I suppose, ALEX Trebek. My Canadian in-laws are staying with us for the week.

On Tuesday, several persons expressed an interest in my plans for blueberry pie; for them, a report:
The U-pick farm we planned to go to this morning closed for the week to allow for further ripening--the ice storm that ravished this part of the state last March resulted in a short, and scanty, season. However, I learned that the same farm had a stand at a local farm market on Wednesdays, and so yesterday my Sister-in-Law and I rushed over and picked up a case of pre-picked berries. ("Local" in this part of the state is a relative term, and the farmer's market is a 60 mile round trip; so no small carbon-footprint on this pie.) The pie is now in the oven: 12"shell, 3 1/2 lbs. fruit, 9 1/2 oz. sugar, a splash of lemon juice and a p[inch of clove for flavor, and thickened with tapioca flour. Off to check it.

Our new puppy "Tillie" fell asleep on my arm as I finished this delightful puzzle. The good news jingle did not wake her & the arm is already dotted with her "teething" nip marks. She's about 9 weeks old and will "sit" on command.

Great puzzle! I enjoyed it except still being stuck on the idea that ART is the answer to the ‚Äúguile‚Äù clue. 
Can someone explain?
Got sidetracked wondering when when and why were going to show up, but that would not fit the theme of course.  ATP sure did bring back memories of APBIO.  Pleasant solve and thanks.

Delightful Thursday! Loved the puzzle. Love the show. Many years ago the Jeopardy College Tournament was taped at nearby Yale and my (then) high school aged son and I were in the audience. Best part was Alex coming out before the show started and answering questions from the crowd. Also, when you watch a live taping you find out how often they sometimes stop the show to check an answer with the judges. Every now and then I catch a very slight hesitation where shows have been spliced together and realize that happens more than we know out here in the tv audience. I miss Alex, but really enjoying Ken‚Äôs tenure after watching his amazing run as a contestant back in the day.

"WHAP?"

c'mon....

Starting at the bottom gave me an odd take on the theme, which was really puzzling...(picture me thinking, "Mary Cassatt, one of my idols, titled a painting 'What's The Tea'???")  duh

This was quite fun and I say Gene Louise did a BANG UP JOB!!!
I think ush was used correctly if you think of escort as a verb and not a noun
I loved this puzzle. Very clever, tricky but with just enough gimmes in the tricky areas to make the solve
good longer clues, but WHAP is not a word, and crossing it with a poorly clued ART (guile?) was just cruel. If you want to cross art with an obscure word maybe clue it in a way that makes sense
Not a fan of this one at all, but hey, at least it wasn‚Äôt a rebus. Pass.
I would guess there‚Äôs a lot of Venn diagram overlap between crossword and Jeopardy fans. I‚Äôm certainly smack in the middle of it. Loved this one!
Yippee! I abandoned my usual NW to SE route on this one as I kept seeing answers jumping out and snaked my way to a personal Thursday Best (by 1 second even!). Fun one, thanks!

"I'll take "Snow White" for $200, Ken."  And speaking of WHO'S THE FAIREST OF THEM ALL,  I'm asking myself: Is this puzzle really fair to everyone?  It was exceedingly fair to me, a longtime Jeopardy buff.  But am I being empathetic enough to others?  I've complained strenuously in the past over "niche" crosswords based on video games and board games I've never even heard of, much less played.  I thought this puzzle was delightful, but I suppose there could be people who felt shut out of the solve.  People who have never watched Jeopardy.  Are there any/many such?

One clue I hated and one warning I want to issue.  Yes, to you, you snotty bot!  Call me MEATBAG even just once and I'll knock you silly.  When I'm finished with you, you'll be nothing more than a big bag of bits and bytes that, like Humpty Dumpty, can never be put back together.  You won't be making up any nicknames for any humans anymore.  Just saying.

I thought the theme of this puzzle was loads of fun.

Amusingly, I started with "rabbi" and "nitro" for 1 & 2 D, but quickly corrected when I got to 13 & 16 A. 
Fun theme for a Thursday. the gold star was never INJEOPARDY and I really liked the homage to Alex. 
I tried, but I don't really care for Ken, and seldom watch anymore.

Deb:
I haven't read through all the comments, but as far as I went, I didn't see this: the poet responsible for ARS POETICA is Horace, not Horatio.
Fun, but really a weird puzzle!  Filled in ATP immediately, but was not expecting it to be the right answer, if you know what I mean.

What is a great way to start a Thursday? Big Jeopardy fan here, so this was extra fun for me. I‚Äôve been watching since Alex Trebek‚Äôs curly hair/ bushy moustache days, and I think he‚Äôd be proud to see what a great job Ken Jennings has done to keep the legend going. (Thank goodness we were spared the Mike Richards years.) And because I‚Äôm surprised no one has linked to it yet, https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=BvUZijEuNDQ
One of my favorite Thursday puzzles of 2025. Bravo!
WHAP?? Not a word!  You don‚Äôt get to make up a word just so you can write a puzzle! Start over if you have to!

I had to check the calendar to make sure it was Thursday because it seemed too easy for me on a Thursday (I've previously complained in this forum about Thursdays lol) This AP Bio student was pleased with the ATP and AP Bio answers to start the day. I filled in all but one of the Jeopardy themed clues without needing crossings.However, the stats don't lie and it wasn't even my best time!
20 mins, 27 seconds today. Rest in peace, Trebek. You're missed.

I was genuinely moved to see ALEX appearing as an answer. What a lovely inclusion. 

And I'll just quote briefly from Sammy Cahn: 

You're hand in hand beneath the trees,
And soon there's music in the breeze.
You're actin' kind of smart
Until your heart just goes WHAP!
Those trees, that breeze -
They're part of the tender trap.

I completed my first Thursday puzzle!

I didn‚Äôt enjoy crosswords and found them frustrating. Then I read the Times‚Äô primer explaining the nuances. It was tremendously helpful! I completed all the Mondays for this year and then the Tuesdays. Once I completed the final Wednesday puzzle, I was ready to tackle my first Thursday. Once I knock out the Thursdays, I‚Äôll be ready for you Friday!

Sunday! Sunday! Sunday! Nitro-burning funny cars in Action! Action! Action! Okay, I'm not saying TURBO boosted dragsters don't exist, because they do, but don't bother taking one to an NHRA-sanctioned event, because they're banned. Too powerful, and more likely to explode.

The puzzle didn't feel much like a Thursday, by the way, but we had a Sunday rebus, so I'm not mad. I also don't remember Lance Armstrong being called "The Boss" or the Melissa McCarthy movie by that name, but Springsteen made it obvious.

Joyfully raced through this one until the SE stopped me in my tracks. I still don't get the [Painted Ladies] connection to WHATSTHETEA. I haven't heard that phrase, and it didn't seem an inevitable rejoinder to Painted Ladies. Neither WHAP nor [Larrup] are words in my dictionary, but at least WHAP was attainable through crosses. Then, finally, I couldn't produce ARSPOETICA thanks to my tea related troubles. I had ALEX down there holding the fort, but couldn't seal the deal for half my solve time.

Still, overall, I really enjoyed the theme!
WHAP?

fun and lovely puzzle! though IMO making the bracketed sections of the themed clues a little more opaque would have led to a more satisfying solve with the 62A revealer clue, it felt a little too obvious to me.

Interesting that the human MEATBAG appears again as the NON-ET in the Supremes.

To be honest, I've lately had my doubts about the humanity of that ennead... Or at least their ACURA, see?

So POSH a Thursday by fAR ABS ORBS me; esp loved the themery clues, very SLUR-py! Thank you GL De Vera.

I decided to hold off on Autocheck one more time and it was fun, if slow. Finally stumped at 2D (_UR_O), I turned to the Column and got the T of 1A which was enough to get me the B of 19A (AP_IO) and the congratulatory note--phony "streak" still going--, but afterwards I looked up "apbio" out of curiosity and failed to find anything relating that to the 19A clue. John Carson, two hours above, remembered it, no help, but fortunately MB of Maine explained it to Jane Wheelaghan eight hours ago.
Fantastic puzzle! Really like the Jeopardy theme, and the variety of connections within each themed clue. Nice one!

really loved the puzzle - very cool theme in homage to one of the absolute gangsters ever of all time. RIP in peace, Alex.
ATP/ALEPH opening crosser was brutal - gave up and revealed as i couldn't figure out either.
i agree w most below - WHAP is an unfortunate stretch.

I asked ChatGPT if it thought I was a MEATBAG just to see what it said, here‚Äôs how it responded. Nice to know someone/some thing still appreciates me:

Well, if we‚Äôre being literal ‚Äî yes, like all humans, you‚Äôre a remarkably sophisticated arrangement of organic matter, water, and various proteins‚Ä¶ basically a ‚Äúmeat bag‚Äù in the most affectionate sci-fi sense.

But you‚Äôre also a thinking, feeling, memory-making, pun-appreciating being, so ‚Äúmeat bag‚Äù is kind of like calling the Mona Lisa ‚Äúsome paint on wood.‚Äù Technically correct, but it misses the magic.
I very much enjoyed the ‚ÄúJeopardy‚Äù theme.  ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs ‚ÄòWho‚Äô?‚Äù was my favorite answer.  Thanks for a completely enjoyable puzzle‚Ä¶and for adding ‚Äúlarrup‚Äù to my vocabulary.

Caption under top photo: 

Juliet asks "Wherefore art thou Romeo?" (not "Where(fore) art thou, Romeo?"

There is an "L" in approximately the middle of "ophthalmologist."

True story: we have a friend who used to work at E! starting back in the late 80s, when it was known as Movietime. He wasn't the most tech-savvy person, but he did use a computer at work. At some point in the 90s a friend asked him to email something, and he said "How can I send you an email? You don't work at E."  That's the day that he learned that the "e" in "email" stood for electronic, not entertainment. ;)

He also came up with a tagline that they declined to use, but I always thought it was brilliant:

If it's happening in the world of entertainment, it's news to us!

I see that Felicia‚Äôs thread got removed (thank you moderators) but it also looks like they took out our conversation about whether DRE was appropriate in a crossword. I thought that was a respectful, thoughtful, lively discussion‚ÄîI wonder why?

Whenever there is a blow up about words like WHAP, onomatopoetic answers, I'm reminded of a section of "Paper Tiger" by George Plimpton..

@Jane Wheelaghan "Jeopardy!" is a popular quiz show in which the contestants are given clues within categories and are expected to come up with the appropriate question befitting the given clue. For example, in the category Summer Olympics Cities, the clue might be, "The most recent one", and the player would have to say, "What is Paris?" The bracketed first part of each theme clue in this puzzle is what the contestant says to the host, Ken Jennings, to select the next clue. The higher the dollar amount, the harder the question, supposedly. The jeopardy is that while the dollar amount is added for a correct answer, the same amount is deducted for an incorrect one, with negative totals possible. Most questions are open to all three players, but a few questions are called Daily Doubles, which can only be answered by the player in control of the board, and that person can wager any amount up to their earnings total. Two rounds are played, with the dollar amounts double in the second round. The game ends with one "Final Jeopardy" question in which players can wager any or all the earnings they have. The clue is revealed, and the players have 30 seconds to write down their question. "Jeopardy!" is on in the early evening Monday through Fridays, with new shows for all but about six weeks in the summer. It's very popular with people who like trivia, so it's perfect for cruciverbalists. Here's a sample: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n8NrMKd1OHo

@CJ - I knew it had to be the answer, but ATP is not really an effective storage molecule for large amounts of energy. It's more like the small change of energy, there to be used on a moment's notice, and constantly being replenished in cells as needed. 

Active cells have enough energy "stored" in ATP to last for no more than about a second. They have a lot of organic phosphate available to rapidly regenerate ATP when needed, and other energy reserves to be tapped when those run out.

But for actual storage of energy, you can't beat lipids and polysaccharides -- fats, glycogen, and starches, and a few other molecules. 

I always taught my students to think of ATP as the energy *currency* of the cell, much like the money you might keep in your pocket. Bulk energy storage would be more analogous to a bank account. You can draw from your bank reserves (say, glycogen) when needed, and when you had some excess money (say, ATP), that is where you would put it. Most people don't keep their entire net worth in the form of currency, just as most cells don't keep their entire energy store in the form of ATP. Only a small portion is stored that way. 

Nevertheless, it's an OK clue/answer, even if a bit misleading.
